qas.question: According to one of the main viewpoints of time, time is part of the fundamental structure of what?
The realist view of time is sometimes referred to as what?
What does the opposing view of time believe time is a part of?
Who is divided about the structure of the universe?
In what order did Gottfried Leibniz believe events occur?
What kind of time did Gottfried Leibniz believe in, as a supporter of Sir Isaac Newton?
How was Immanuel Kant described, since he also believed in Newtonian time?
What did Sir Issac Newton believe that you could not do in time?
According to one of the main viewpoints of time, time is part of the view of what?
What is the realest view of time sometimes known as?
What does the opposing view of time believe the universe is a part of?
Who subscribed to the opposing view?
Who believe time is neither a structure or a view?

context: Two contrasting viewpoints on time divide <b3_0>many prominent philosophers<b3_0/>. One view is that time is part of the fundamental structure of <a0_0><b8_0>the universe<b8_0/><a0_0/>—a dimension independent of events, in which events occur <b4_0>in sequence<b4_0/>. <b11_0>Sir Isaac Newton<b11_0/> subscribed to this <b6_0>realist<b6_0/> view, and hence it is sometimes referred to as <a1_0><b5_0><b9_0>Newtonian time<b9_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>. The opposing view is that time does not refer to any kind of "container" that events and objects "move through", nor to any entity that "flows", but that it is instead part of <a2_0><b10_0>a fundamental intellectual structure<b10_0/><a2_0/> (together with space and number) within which humans sequence and compare events. This second view, in the tradition of <b12_0>Gottfried Leibniz and Immanuel Kant<b12_0/>, holds that time is neither an event nor a thing, and thus is not itself measurable nor can it be <b7_0>travel<b7_0/>led.
